chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text: In this problem, we are tasked to solve for the cost of equity using the concept of weighted average cost of capital (WACC)
The weighted average cost of capital (WACC), also known as the cost of equity, refers to the rate that the company is expected to sustain in order to pay for the finances of their assets.

**a.)** For this problem, since the given debt-to-equity ratio is $1.25$, this means that for $1$ equity, there is $1.25$ debt. This gives a total value of $2.25$. 

Since we have the total value of $2.25$, we can solve for the weight of both the debt and the equity.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Weight of equity}&=\dfrac{1.00}{2.25}\\[15 pt]
&=0.444\\[15 pt]
\text{Weight of debt}&=\dfrac{1.25}{2.25}\\[15 pt]
&=0.556
\end{aligned}$$

Now, to solve for the cost of equity, we will use the formula for WACC. We can recall this formula as:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{WACC}&=\text{Weight of equity} \times \text{Cost of equity}\\
&+(\text{Weight of debt} \times \text{Cost of debt}) \times (1-\text{Tax rate})
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values provided in the problem, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
0.083&=0.444 \times \text{Cost of equity}\\
&+(0.556 \times 0.051) \times (1-0.21)
\end{aligned}$$

Simplifying the equation above by isolating the unknown, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
0.444 \times \text{Cost of equity}&=0.0606\\[15 pt]
\text{Cost of equity}&=\dfrac{0.0606}{0.444}\\[15 pt]
&=0.1365
\end{aligned}$$

The cost of equity for this is $0.1365$ or $13.65\%$

Using the values stated in the problem and the cost of equity computed in Step 5, we can solve for the unlevered cost of equity by substituting these to the formula above. 

$$\begin{aligned}
0.1365&=\text{Unlevered cost of equity}\\
&+(\text{Unlevered cost of equity} -0.051) \times (1-0.21) \times 1.25
\end{aligned}$$

Simplifying the formula by isolating the unknown will give us:

$$\begin{aligned}
1.9875 \times \text{Unlevered cost of equity}&=0.1365 +0.0504\\[15 pt]
1.9875 \times \text{Unlevered cost of equity}&=0.1869\\[15 pt]
\text{Unlevered cost of equity}&=\dfrac{0.1869}{1.9875}\\[15 pt]
&=0.09404
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the unlevered cost of equity, or the cost of equity in a debt-free model is $0.09404$ or $9.404\%$

**c.)** For this, we will use three different values for the debt-equity ratio to solve for the value of the cost of equity. In this problem, we will again use the formula in Step 6. 

For debt-equity ratio equal to $2$:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of equity}&=0.09404 +(0.09404\times0.79 \times2)\\[15 pt]
&=0.2426
\end{aligned}$$

For a debt-equity ratio of $2$, the cost of equity is $0.2426$ or $24.26\%$

For debt-equity ratio equal to $1$:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of equity}&=0.09404 +(0.09404\times0.79 \times1)\\[15 pt]
&=0.1683
\end{aligned}$$

For a debt-equity ratio of $1$, the cost of equity is $0.1683$ or $16.83\%$

For debt-equity ratio equal to $0$:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of equity}&=0.09404 +(0.09404\times0.79 \times0)\\[15 pt]
&=0.09404
\end{aligned}$$

For a debt-equity ratio of $0$, the cost of equity is $0.09404$ or $9.404\%$

In summary, we can see that a higher debt-equity ratio shows a higher cost of equity for the given firm. Moreover, at a debt-equity ratio of $0$, the cost of equity is the same as the unlevered cost of equity since the unlevered cost of equity functions in a model that is debt-free.
